moves.1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 Nf6 4. Nc3 Be7: Such an advance in the Queen's Gambit is generally two-edged. In this case, however, White is in a position to make it because Black, with his last move, has wasted a tempo in the fight for the center.
moves.7... c6: We now have a familiar blocked Pawn chain.
moves.8. b4 Nbd7 9. Bb2 Qc7 10. Qc2 e5 11. O-O: The King will be safer here than on the opposite wing.
moves.11... e4: Black plans ...P-KB4-5, undermining White's Pawn chain.
moves.12. Nh4 Nb8 13. g3 Ne8 14. Ng2 f5 15. h4: Now that ...P-B5 has been stopped forever, White will be able to devote his whole attention to the Queen-side.
moves.15... Bd8 16. a4 b6 17. b5: Threatening 18 PxBP QxBP 19 NxQP! winning a Pawn (19.... QxN?? 20 B-B4!)
White will now benefit if Black exchanges either of the pawns.
moves.20... Bc7: Black wants to exchange off the White Knight on KB4, to reduce the pressure on his QP.
moves.21. cxb6 Bxf4 22. gxf4 Bd7 23. Kd2: The QB file is no longer safe for White's King.
White proceeds to maintain the initiative with a surprising maneuver.
